text:
AoL

Generalizing and Using Properties of Polygons: Exploration, Analysis

Algebraic Expressions and Equations: Analysis

Emerging Mathematical Ideas

Extend understanding and applications of angle measure to include angles created by two intersecting lines or by two parallel lines cut by a third intersecting line.

Explore, identify, and describe angle relationships created by intersecting lines including:

  • adjacent angles which are two angles that share a common endpoint and a common ray (side),
  • vertical angles that are formed when two lines insect. They share a common endpoint, do not share a common ray (side) and have equal measures,
  • supplementary angles which are a pair of angles whose sum is 180°,
  • complementary angles which are a pair of angles whose sum is 90°, and
  • parallel lines are lines that never intersect and are always the same distance apart.

Use the angle relationships above to write equations and solve multi-step problems involving angles formed with intersecting lines

NWDYK

Describe what you know about angles formed by intersecting lines. Include parallel lines and the angles formed by a line that intersects the parallel lines in your description.

Launch (Getting Started)

Connecting to Prior Knowledge

Introduce the vocabulary of scale factor and connect it to the work from previous problems. Discussing the pair of similar rectangles below can spring board the conversation.

tiles.title: Similar rectangles with a scale factor of 3

text:
Suggested Questions

  • How would you describe the relationship between the side lengths when going from the large shape to the smaller shape and vice versa? (Answers will vary. Focus the conversation on the lengths of the sides.)
  • What would you multiply each side length of the small rectangle by to get the larger rectangle? (3)
  • What would you multiply each side length of the larger rectangle to get the smaller rectangle? (1/3)
  • What scale factor was used to turn Mug into Zug? (2)
  • What scale factor was used to turn Mug into Bug? (3)

Presenting the Challenge

Tell the class that the challenge is to use the criteria of corresponding angles and side lengths to determine which rectangles (mouths) and which triangles (noses) are similar.

The following statements are true for similar figures.

  • Corresponding angles have the same measure.
  • Corresponding side lengths from one figure to the other are multiplied by the same scale factor.

Because corresponding sides and angles constitute an essential idea, you may want to be explicit with students about the need for labeling figures. The vertices of the Wump mouths and noses are not labeled. You could label these vertices to clear up any difficulties in referring to specific sides later. (Language and Time)
